titleStmt.title: Multiple-buyer multiple-vendor multi-product multi-constraint supply chain problem with stochastic demand and variable lead-time: A harmony search algorithm

analytic.title: Multiple-buyer multiple-vendor multi-product multi-constraint supply chain problem with stochastic demand and variable lead-time: A harmony search algorithm

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Supply chain management Multi-buyer Multi-vendor Partial back ordering Variable lead-time Integer nonlinear programming Harmony search algorithm Genetic algorithm

div.p: In this paper, a multi-buyer multi-vendor supply chain problem is considered in which there are several products, each buyer has limited capacity to purchase products, and each vendor has warehouse limitation to store products. In this chain, the demand of each product is stochastic and follows a uniform distribution. The lead-time of receiving products from a vendor to a buyer is assumed to vary linearly with respect to the order quantity of the buyer and the production rate of the vendor. For each product, a fraction of the shortage is backordered and the rest are lost. The ordered product quantities are placed in multiple of pre-defined packets and there are service rate constraints for the buyers. The goal is to determine the reorder points, the safety stocks, and the numbers of shipments and packets in each shipment of the products such that the total cost of the supply chain is minimized. We show that the model of this problem is of an integer nonlinear programming type and in order to solve it a harmony search algorithm is employed. To validate the solution and to compare the performance of the proposed algorithm, a genetic algorithm is utilized as well. A numerical illustration and sensitivity analysis are given at the end to show the applicability of the proposed methodology in real-world supply chain problems.

div.head: Introduction and literature review
div.p: The network design of a supply chain is considered a strategic decision problem that provides an optimal platform for the effective and efficient supply chain management. A single-vendor (manufacturer) multi-buyer (SV-MB) supply chain involves a vendor producing a product at a finite rate and then supplying it to several buyers, to satisfy their fixed rates of demand. A multi-vendor single-buyer (MV-SB) supply chain involves several vendors producing a product at a finite rate and then supplying it to a buyer, to satisfy his fixed rates of demand. While both of the SV-MB and MV-SB supply-chain problems have received a considerable attention in the literature, there is little (or no) effort in the literature for the multi-vendor multi-buyer (MV-MB) problem in which there are several vendors supplying the demands of several buyers. In the next Section, related works on the single-vendor single-buyer problem is first reviewed. Then in Section 1.2, some related research works on the multiple-vendor or multiple-buyer problem are surveyed.

div.head: Multi-buyer or multi-vendor problem
div.p: Weng [14] further extended Parlar and Wang's [1] work with a single vendor and multi buyers by considering both allunit and incremental quantity discount policies. Chu and Leon [15] considered the problem of coordinating a single-vendor multi-buyer inventory system when there are privacy restrictions in the information required to solve the problem. The objective function and the cost parameters of each facility were regarded as private information that no other facilities in the system have access to. Moreover, each facility was responsible to specify its own replenishment policy. Abdul-Jalbar et al. [16] introduced a multi-echelon inventory system in which one vendor supplies an item to multiple buyers. In their model, the vendor produces the item at a finite rate and the customer demand occurs at each buyer at a constant rate. There is a holding cost per unit stored per unit time at the vendor and the buyers. Hoque [17] extended a close relationship between a manufacturer and buyers for a costless way of benefit sharing. He introduced three models, two of which transfer with equal batches (part of a lot) and the third with unequal batches of the product. He et al. [18] developed a productioninventory model for deteriorating items with multiple-market demand, where each market has a different selling season and a different constant demand rate. Glock [19] tackled both the supplier selection and the lot-size decision problem in a multivendors single-buyer environment. In this problem, the buyer sources a product from heterogeneous suppliers and the objective is to minimize the total system costs. Sinha and Sarma [20] developed a single-vendor multi-buyer discount-pricing model with stochastic demand. The vendor offers multiple pricing schedules to encourage the buyers to adopt the global optimal policy instead of their individual optimal ordering policy. Chan et al. [21] considered a coordinated single-vendor multi-buyer supply chain model by synchronizing ordering and production cycles with delayed payments that are based on the buyers' order intervals. Hoque [22] developed a generalized single-vendor multi-buyer supply chain model individually by extending the idea of such synchronization.

In this paper, a closer to reality multi-product supply-chain problem consisting several buyers and vendors is considered where there are some real-world constraints. We use the assumptions of Taleizadeh et al. [23] research, in which the leadtime is varying linearly with respect to the order quantity of the buyers and the production rates of the vendors. The demand follows a uniform probability distribution and the (r, q) policy is used to replenish the inventory. A fraction of a shortage is backordered and that the orders are placed in multiple of pre-defined packets. The improvements of the current research over the Taleizadeh et al.'s [23] work are as follows:

1. A multiple-buyer multiple-vendor chain is modeled. 2. Several constraints such as the service rate, the budget, and the warehouse space are considered to make the problem closer to reality. 3. A new meta-heuristic algorithm of the harmony search is employed to solve the obtained integer nonlinear model of the problem.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the problem with its assumptions is defined. The mathematical model of the problem is developed in Section 3. In Section 4, a solution approach based on the harmony search is proposed. In order to illustrate the proposed algorithm, a numerical example is presented in Section 5. Finally, the conclusion and some recommendations for future research are given in Section 6.

div.head: Problem definition
div.p: Consider a multi-buyer multi-vendor supply chain problem with several products and constraints in which each buyer uses the classical (r, q) inventory control policy to order his product. In this policy, the demand is stochastic and when the inventory level of the product reaches to point r, the buyer will order (the order quantity is q). Further, since in real-world inventory environments, increases in buyers' order quantities cause the production quantities, the production time, and the packing time to increase as well, the lead-time does not take a constant value. Hence, a variable lead-time defined as a linear function of both the buyer's order quantity and production rate is considered in this research, in which a fixed delay due to transportation, nonproductive time, etc., is added.

The relationship between the vendors and the buyers are described as follows: for the ith product, i = 1,2,. . ., p, the jth buyer, j = 1,2,. . . , n, orders a lot of size q ijk to the kth vendor k = 1,2,. . ., K and incurs an ordering cost. Based on the demands, the vendor manufactures each product in lots with a finite production rate and incurs a setup cost. Then, the buyers receives ns o ijk shipments, each containing M ijk packets of n i products, i.e.,q ijk = u i M ijk and incurs a transportation cost for each shipment. The jth buyer places his order when his on-hand inventory of the ith product reaches a reorder point r ij .

In this research, four groups of constraint are considered. The first one is the service level constraint that is considered for each product of each buyer. The second one is the batch order constraint in which the orders are placed in multiple of predefined packets. The third group of constraints is the budget constraint for each buyer and finally the fourth one is the warehouse space limitation for each vendor. The cost function of the buyers include the shortage cost that include both the backorder and lost-sale, the fixed order cost, the purchasing cost, the holding and transportation costs. The cost function of the vendors contains the set up and the holding costs. The objective is to determine the reorder points of each product for each buyer, the order quantities of each product for each buyer to each vendor, and the number of shipments of the each product for each buyer from each vendor such that the expected total cost of the supply chain is minimized. Fig. 1 depicts the supply chain system of the problem under consideration.

div.head: Products
div.p: In the next section, a mathematical formulation of the problem at hand will be developed. To do this the parameters and the decision variables of the model are first defined.

div.head: Mathematical formulation
div.p: For i = 1, 2, . . ., p, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, and k = 1, 2, . . . , K the decision variables and the parameters that are required for the mathematical formulation of the problem are given in the following two Sections.

div.p: reorder point of the ith product for the jth buyer ns o ijk number of shipments of the ith product from the kth vendor to the jth buyer m ijk expected number of the packets of the ith product ordered by the jth buyer to the kth vendor q ijk expected amount of the ith product ordered by the jth buyer to the kth vendor

div.head: The buyers' total costs
div.p: In spite of Taleizadeh et al. [23] who extended the single-vendor single-buyer supply chain problem with variable leadtime and stochastic demand of Ben-Daya and Hariga [24] to contain several products and constraints, in this paper, a model for the multi-buyer, multi-vendor, multi-product, multi-constraint supply chain problem is developed. To do this, a model for a single-buyer single-vendor problem is first developed for one product and then it will be extended to include several buyers, multiple vendors, and several products.

Since it was assumed that shortages are allowed in the forms of backorder and lost-sales, the cost function of a single buyer include the backorder, the lost-sales, the fixed ordering, the purchasing, the holding, and the transportations costs. Hence, the total expected cost of the buyer per unit time is:
div.formula: TCðbÞ ¼ C A b þ C H b þ C B b þ C L b þ C T b :ð1Þ
div.p: Fig. 2. The kth vendor's inventory graph.

Referring to Fig. 2 that shows the vendor's inventory graph, the expected total ordering cost and the expected total transportation cost of the buyer, ðC A b Þ and ðC T b Þ respectively, are obtained as:
div.formula: C A b ¼ A ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk ;ð2Þ
C T b ¼ l ijk q ijk A t ijk ;ð3Þ
div.p: According to Hadley-Whitin's [25] the expected on hand inventory per unit time when demand is a random variable is:
div.formula: I ij ¼ q ij 2 þ SS ij ;ð4Þ
div.p: where, based on the derivation given in Appendix A, SS ij is:
div.formula: SS ij ¼ r ij À X K k¼1 l ijk q ijk P ik þ c ijk þ ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ :ð5Þ
div.p: Thus,
div.formula: C H b ¼ h b ij P K k¼1 q ijk 2 þ r ij À X K k¼1 l ijk q ijk P ik þ c ijk þ ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ 0 B @ 1 C A:ð6Þ
div.p: Furthermore, based on Appendix B, the backorder and lost-sale costs are:
div.formula: C B b ¼ p ij k ij P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ ;ð7Þ
C L b ¼ pij ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ :ð8Þ
div.p: Hence, the total cost per unit time of the jth buyer for the ith product and the kth vendor is obtained as:
div.formula: TCðbÞ ¼ C A b þ C H b þ C B b þ C L b þ C T b ¼ A ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk þ h b ij P K k¼1 q ijk 2 þ r ij À X K k¼1 l ijk q ijk P ik þ c ijk þ ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ 0 B @ 1 C A þ p ij k ij P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À d Min ijk þ pij ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ þ l ijk q ijk A t ijk :ð9Þ

div.head: The vendors' total costs
div.p: Based on Taleizadeh et al. [23] who developed the vendor's total costs including C Av and C Hv for multi-buyer single-vendor system, in this research the fixed ordering and holding costs of a vendors are obtained using Eqs. (10) and (11), respectively.
div.formula: C Av ¼ A p ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk ;ð10Þ
C Hv ¼ h v ik l ijk 2 ns o ijk 1 À l ijk P ik À 1 þ 2 l ijk P ik ! :ð11Þ
div.p: Thus, the kth vendor's total cost for the ith product and the jth buyer becomes:
div.formula: TCðvÞ ¼ C Av þ C Hv ¼ A p ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk þ h v ik q ijk 2 ns o ijk 1 À l ijk P ik À 1 þ 2 l ijk P ik ! :ð12Þ
div.p: 3.5. The chain's total costs From Eqs. ( 9) and ( 12), the total expected cost of the supply chain for the ith product, jth buyer and kth vendor is:
div.formula: TC ¼ TCðbÞ þ TCðvÞ ¼ C A b þ C H b þ C B b þ C L b þ C T b þ C Av þ C Hv ¼ A ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk þ h b ij P K k¼1 q ijk 2 þ r ij À X K k¼1 l ijk q ijk P ik þ c ijk þ ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ 0 B @ 1 C A þ p ij k ij P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ þ pij ð1 À k ij Þ P K k¼1 l ijk P K k¼1 d Max ijk À r ij 2 2 P K k¼1 ns o ijk q ijk P K k¼1 ðd Max ijk À d Min ijk Þ þ l ijk q ijk A t ijk þ A p ik l ijk ns o ijk q ijk þ h v ik q ijk 2 ns o ijk 1 À l ijk P ik À 1 þ 2 l ijk P ik ! :ð13Þ

div.head: The constraints
div.p: Since the shortages of the ith product for jth buyer only occur when the demand is more than the reorder point, according to what is derived in Appendix C, the service level constraint is obtained as
div.formula: r ij P X K k¼1 q ijk P ik þ c ijk d Max ijk À d Min ijk " # a ij þ X K k¼1 d Min ijk q ijk P ik þ c ijk ;ð14Þ
div.p: where a ij is the lower limit of the service level of the ith product for the jth buyer.

Furthermore, since the orders should be placed in multiple of pre-defined packet sizes of u i , for the order quantity of each product ("i; i = 1,2,. . . , p) from each buyer (" j; j = 1,2,. . ., n) to each vendor ("k; k = 1,2,. . . , K), we will have:
div.formula: q ijk ¼ u i m ijk :ð15Þ
div.p: Moreover, the budget constraint for each buyer ("j;
div.formula: j = 1,2,. . . , n) is, X p i¼1 X K k¼1 C i q ijk 6 W j ;ð16Þ
div.p: where C i is the purchasing price of the ith product, q ijk is the order quantity of the ith product from jth buyer to the kth vendor and W j is the total budget of the jth buyer. Finally, the warehouse constraint of each vendor is formulated as follows.
div.formula: f i q ijk 2 ns o ijk 1 À l ijk P ik À 1 þ 2 l ijk P ik ! 6 F k ;ð17Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: q ijk 2 ns o ijk 1 À l ijk P ik À 1 þ 2 l ijk P ik h i
div.p: is the expected inventory of the ith product that is obtained by subtracting the accumulated buyer consumption from the accumulated vendor production in Fig. 2, f i is the required space per unit of the i th product, and the kth vendor's total available warehouse space is F k .

div.head: The multi-buyer multi-vendor model
div.p: The single-buyer single-vendor single-product model of the problem given in Eqs. ( 13)-( 17) can be easily extended to a multi-buyer multi-vendor model containing several products and multiple constraints as follows.

div.head: A harmony search solution algorithm
div.p: While new ways are developed in the literature to optimize problems for less than a century, nature has used various ways of optimization for millions of million years. Recently, scientists mimicked nature to solve different kinds of complex optimization problems. Most of these problems are so complicated and time consuming that one cannot use an exact algorithm to solve them. Thus, typically some non-precise algorithms are used to find a near optimum solution in a shorter period. These algorithms are called meta-heuristics [26]. Some of these algorithms such as particle swarm optimization (Taleizadeh et al. [23]), memetic algorithm (Pishvaee et al. [5]), ant colony optimization (Silva et al. [27]), genetic-ant colony algorithm (Lin and Wang [28]), genetic algorithm (Naso et al. [29]), and simulated annealing (Lim and Zhu [30]) have been employed to solve complex supply chain problems. However, the meta-heuristic harmony search algorithm, due to its good performances in solving complex optimization problems, is utilized in this research to solve the integer non-linear programming model in (18). In addition, to validate the results and to compare its performance, a genetic algorithm of Taleizadeh et al. [31] is employed to solve the problem as well.

The harmony search (HS) is one of the newly developed meta-heuristic algorithms inspired by the act of music improvisation process of musician groups where musicians in an ensemble continue to polish their pitches in order to obtain better harmony [32]. This algorithm seeks the optimum solution of a complex optimization problem by generating random vector solutions in a Harmony Memory (HM) that are improved iteration by iteration with some pitch adjusting and updating methods to reach global optimum. In short, according to the analogy of improvisation and optimization, fantastic harmony is considered as global optimum, esthetic standard is determined by the objective function, pitches of instruments are desired values of the variables, and each practice is the same in each iteration [32]. This algorithm starts with an initialization process that is described in the next subsection.

div.head: Initialization
div.p: The initialization process contains parameter initialization and HM initialization. The pitch adjusting rate (P PAR ), the number of decision variables (N), the maximum number of improvisations (NI), the harmony memory size (HMS), and the harmony memory considering rate (P HMCR ) are the five parameters of the HS algorithm. The pitch adjustment is similar to the adjustment of each musical instrument in a jazz so that pleasing harmony can be achieved. The P PAR is the probability of the pitch adjustment where its typical value ranges from 0.3 to 0.99 and in this research three values of 0.5, 0.7, and 0.9 are considered for P PAR . The number of decision variables of the optimization problem (N) is fully depended on the characteristics of the problem. The objective function will be evaluated NI times as the maximum number of improvisations (iterations) in which three values of 500, 1000, and 1500 are considered. The HMS is the number of simultaneous solution vectors in HM, where small values are recommended in the literature [32][33][34][35]. In this research three values of 10, 15, and 30 are considered for HMS. Finally, the P HMCR is the probability of choosing HM. As very small values of P HMCR decreases the efficiency of the algorithm toward a pure random search algorithm, selecting larger probabilities of choosing HM (i.e. P0.9) is desired and in this research, three values of 0.9, 0.95, and 0.99 are considered for P HMCR .

The HM is a two-dimensional matrix with HMS rows and N + 1 columns where the objective function for each solution vector is specified in the last column. Fig. 3 shows a sample HM in which Y ij (i is an index of the decision variable in vector Y and j is an index of the vector solution in HM) is one of the decision variables used in HS algorithm and f(Y j ) is the value of the objective function for the jth vector solution. The HM is initialized with randomly generated solutions in a specific range limited by upper and lower bounds determined by the problem at hand.

div.head: New harmony generation
div.p: Random selection, HM consideration, and pitch adjustment are the basis of the new harmony improvisation. In a random selection rule, the new value of each decision variable Y 0 i is randomly generated within the range of the vector solution Y i . Then, Y 0 ¼ Y 0 1 ; Y 0 2 ; . . . ; Y 0 N Â Ã will represent the new vector solution. In HM algorithm, the random choosing within HM occurs with probability P HMCR and the random selection is performed with probability (1 À P HMCR ). Algorithm 1 shows the choosing and the selection processes [32].
Algorithm 1. The choosing and selection processes of the HM algorithm
div.formula: For i = 1: N If Rand i < P HMCR ; Rand i $ Uni(0, 1)
Y 0 i Y 0 i 2 Y 1 i ; Y 2 i ; . . . ; Y HMS i h i Else Y 0 i
div.p: generate a new one within the range End If End For Table 9 The best results for the buyers of the third vendor by HS algorithm.

div.head: Product
div.p: First Buyer In pitch adjustment, every component obtained by the memory consideration is examined to determine whether it should be pitch adjusted or not. The value of the decision variable is changed using Eq. ( 19) with probability of P PAR . This value is kept without any change with probability (1 À P PAR ). In Eq. ( 19) for each vector component, the selection for increasing or decreasing are carried out with the same probability.
div.formula: ns o i13 m i13 q i13 r i1 SS i1
Y 0 ¼ Y 0 AE ðrandÞðBWCÞ; rand $ U½0; 1:ð19Þ
div.p: where BWC denotes the amount of changes for pitch adjustment.

div.head: Harmony memory update and stopping criteria
div.p: The constraint handling part of the algorithm is performed before updating the HM. The constraint handling part checks whether all of the constraints of the model are satisfied or not. If they are satisfied, then the HM update action occurs. In this step, by the objective function evaluation, if the new fitness value is better than the worst case in the HM, the worst harmony vector is replaced by the new solution vector.

The last step in a HS algorithm is to check if the algorithm has found a solution that is good enough to meet the user's expectations. In this research, when a predetermined number of consecutive iterations is reached, the algorithm is stopped.
In summary, the steps involved in the proposed HS algorithm of this research are:
Step 1: Initialize both the parameters and the HM of the HS algorithm.
Step 2: Make a new vector Y 0 . Then, for each component Y 0 i : With probability P HMCR pick the component from memory, With probability 1 À P HMCR pick a new random value in the allowed range.

div.head: Table 10
div.p: The best results for the buyers of the first vendor by GA.

div.head: Product
div.p: First buyer Step 3: Pitch adjustment: For each component Y 0 i : With probability P PAR , a small change is made to Y 0 i . With probability 1 À P PAR do nothing.
div.formula: ns o i11 m i11 q i11 r i1 SS i1
div.p: Step 4: By the objective function evaluation if Y 0 is better than the worst Y j in the memory, then replace Y j by Y 0 (using Algorithm 1).
Step 5: Go to step 2 until a maximum number of iterations is reached.

div.head: A numerical illustration
div.p: Consider a supply chain system with three vendors, five buyers, and five products. Each buyer uses the classical (r, q) inventory control policy in which the demand is stochastic and when the inventory level reaches to point r, the buyer will order q products. The lead-time of the ordered products by a buyer to a vendor is a linear function of the order quantity and the vendor production rate plus a fixed delay due to transportation, nonproductive time, etc. The general data of the system under consideration is given in Tables 123456. Besides, the vendor's total available warehouse space is F k = 10,000 m 3 ; "k; k = 1, 2, 3.

Both the proposed HS and GA have 225 variables (three decision variables for each of the 5 products, three vendors, and 5 buyers (3 Â 5 Â 3 Â 5 = 225)). Tables 789show the best results of the three decision variables for each buyer obtained by HS algorithm. show the best results of these variables obtained by employing the GA. In these tables, SS ij and q ijk are the safety stock of ith product for the jth buyer and the order quantity of ith product for the jth buyer to kth vendor, respectively. Furthermore, r ij is the reorder point of the ith product for the jth buyer, ns o ijk is number of shipments of the ith product from the kth vendor to the jth buyer and m ijk is expected number of the packets of the ith product ordered by the jth buyer to the kth vendor.

div.head: Table 11
div.p: The best results for the buyers of the second vendor by GA.

div.head: Product
div.p: First buyer The results in Tables 789show that the minimum values of the buyers' and the vendors' total costs obtained using HS algorithm are 1,287,022 and 312,300, respectively, resulting in the chain minimum cost of 1,599,322. Moreover, based on the results in Tables 10-12 these figures are 1,334,530, 329,540, and 1,664,070 employing GA. In other words, the proposed HS algorithm performs better than GA in terms of not only the chain total cost, but also in terms of the buyers and the vendors' costs.
div.formula: ns o i12 m i12 q i12 r i2 SS i1
div.p: Different values of the HS parameters that were used to obtain the solution are given in Table 13. All of the possible combinations of the parameters in Table 13 are employed and using the min (min) criterion, the best combination of the parameters has been selected. In fact, 81 (3 Â 3 Â 3 Â 3 = 81) permutations of parameters are checked for each of which at least 5 runs were made. As a result, the problem is examined at least 405 times (81 Â 5 = 405) and the best solution and the best combination of the HS parameters are selected. The best combination of the parameters is NI = 1500, P PAR = 0.7, P HMCR = 0.99, HMS = 10. Table 14 shows the numbers of the variables and constraints in several situations that are based on the number of products P = 5, the number of buyers n = 5, and the number of vendors K = 3. Furthermore, the convergence path of the best results of the objective function from the HS method is shown in Fig. 4.

div.head: Table 13
div.p: The parameters of the HS algorithm.

div.head: Sensitivity analysis
div.p: To study the effects of the parameter changes on the optimal result derived by the proposed harmony search algorithm, sensitivity analysis is performed by changing (increasing or decreasing) the parameters by 10%, 25% and 50% and taking one parameter at a time, keeping the remaining parameters at their original values. The effects of parameter changing on the objective function's values of the buyers, the vendors, and the chain are shown in Tables 151617.

Based on the results obtained from Tables 15-17, one can see that the objective function is highly sensitive to the changes in the values of the demand and production rates (d ijk , P ik ). Further, on the one hand, the objective function is moderately sensitive to the changes in the values of the minimum service level, holding costs, and the buyer budgets
div.formula: ða ij ; h v ik ; h b ij ; W j Þ.
div.p: On the other hand, changes in the values of the partial back ordering rate (k ij ), back order cost (p ij ) and lost sale costs ðp ij Þ have no serious effect on the values of the objective function. The increasing cases of 25% and 50% in the values of the service level and partial back ordering rate is not possible, as they make their sum greater than one.

div.head: Conclusion and recommendations for future research
div.p: In this paper, a multi-buyer multi-vendor supply chain problem with several products and constraints was investigated in which each buyer had limited budget to purchase his products and each vendor had warehouse space limitation to store the products. In this chain, the demand was stochastic and followed a uniform distribution. The lead-time of each ordered product from each buyer to each vendor was assumed to change linearly with respect to the order quantity of the buyer and the production rate of the vendor. The products shortages were considered in the forms of backorders and lost-sales. The objective was to determine the reorder point, the safety stock, the numbers of shipments, the numbers of packets in each shipment of each product ordered by each buyer to the vendors such that the expected total costs of the chain is minimized. The mathematical model of the problem was developed and shown to be of integer nonlinear type and a meta-heuristic solution algorithm of the harmony search was proposed to solve the model. In order to validate the results obtained and to compare the performance of the proposed HS algorithm, a genetic algorithm was utilized as well. A numerical illustration was given to demonstrate the performance and the applicability of the proposed methodology to solve closer to reality supply chain problems. The results showed the better performance of the proposed HS algorithm in terms of the chain total costs, the buyers' cost, and the vendors' cost. A sensitivity analysis was performed at the end to show the effects of the parameter changes on the costs of the buyers, the vendors, and the supply chain.

For future research, considering other kinds of inventory control policy and investigating some other probability distribution functions or uncertainty modeling for of the demand are recommended. The type of the assumed probability distribution has no effect on the way the solution algorithm is developed. However, as the probability distribution changes, different formulation will be obtained.
